results.title: Whales
results.brief_description: WHALES - a film as big, beautiful and complex as its subjects. Throughout history the destinies of men and whales have been closely linked. From primitive peoples, pitted against these mighty creatures with just a harpoon and cunning, whaling meant survival. In the 19th century whaling epitomised adventure, excitement and discovery. Today, whaling means big business, power and money. Now its the whales who excite our curiosity and demand our compassion. “Whales” is a thought-provoking look at our complex feelings of love, hate, necessity and fear towards the animals who share our planet as we struggle to balance our needs against their survival.

results.title: Whales
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau”.
Shows Jacques Costeau and his crew touring the sea in the last surviving wooden whaling boat, viewing an experiment with a whale at marine world in California and conducting a series of studies in the Indian Ocean.

results.title: Westminster Abbey. - [Rev. version]
results.brief_description: This film is a revised version of “Westminster Abbey, Title Code 011796”. It traces the history of Westminster Abbey in relationship to its importance in the life of the English Church and nation and as a valuable record of the development of English eccleseastical architecture over the centuries. Musical score by Ecaro Pastore. Narration by Terence Alexander.

results.title: Westminster Abbey
results.brief_description: The history of Westminster Abbey is the history of England. Here Parliament once met; here for centuries the Kings and Queens of England have been crowned; and here are buried illustrious Englishmen of all times - sovereigns, statesmen, poets, scientists, musicians. In the nave is the tomb of an Unknown Warrior, brought from Flanders in 1920 as representative of all the nameless British dead in the War of 1914-18. Westminster Abbey is a fine example of early English architecture. Concludes with scenes of the coronation of King George VIth. The film is accompanied by the Westminster Choir and the London Symphony Orchestra with original music composed and conducted by Horace Shepherd. Commentator: Alvar Lidell.

results.title: Westgate Bridge
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson and Cine Service Films
results.brief_description: The story of the eventful construction of Westgate Bridge which will eventually link Melbourne’s southern and western suburbs. The projected date of completion is now 1977, but industrial disputes and a calamitous collapse of part of the structure have delayed the estimated date of completion.

results.title: Westernport Bay: the islands
results.creator_credit: Harris Smart, ABC-TV (Australia) and Film Victoria
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Changing Landscape”.
Charles Nancarrow, Wildlife Management Officer, shos the variety of land usage on the Islands of Westernport bay and its effect on the wildlife.

results.title: Westernport Bay: the ecosystem
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Changing Landscape”.
Graham Pizzey, photographer of wild birds runs a reserve where people can view the birds without affecting the natural environment. He stresses the importance of the need for environmental studies in the Westernport region before it is disturbed by industry.

results.title: Westernport Bay: the catchment
results.creator_credit: Harris Smart and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Changing Landscape”.
Grant Hazelgrove shows the many recreational and other activities in Westernport Bay and discusses the role of the Westernport Catchment Co-ordinating Group in controlling the use of resources which have an impact on the bay.

results.title: Western waterways
results.brief_description: From its source in the Cotswold Hills, the Bristol Avon River winds its way through quiet pastoral country, presently reaching the city of Bath, famous for its period architecture and its mineral springs. The Avon flows through the industrial city of Bristol, one of the busiest ports of Britain, and near the sea at Avonmouth, the dockyards line the river banks.
